title: Traditional Gajar Ka Halwa
description: Classic North Indian gajar ka halwa made with slow-cooked carrots, milk, ghee, and khoya

ingredients.name: red carrots, peeled and medium grated

steps.instruction: Wash, peel, and medium-grate the carrots. Keep them aside.
Add grated carrots and milk to a heavy-bottom kadhai. Cook on medium flame, stirring every few minutes.
Continue cooking until the milk completely reduces and the carrots become soft and glossy.
Add desi ghee and cook on medium flame, stirring continuously, until ghee separates and raw smell disappears.
Lower the flame, add sugar, and mix well. Cook until the released moisture evaporates and the halwa thickens again.
Add crumbled khoya and mix thoroughly. Cook until the halwa becomes heavy and rich.
Add cardamom powder and mix well to evenly distribute the flavour.
In a small pan, lightly fry cashews, almonds, and raisins in a little ghee until aromatic.
Add the fried dry fruits to the halwa and mix gently. Switch off the heat.
Serve hot, garnished with extra nuts if desired.

title: Paneer Butter Masala
description: Rich and creamy North Indian curry made with paneer in a buttery tomato-based gravy

steps.instruction: Heat oil and 1 tablespoon butter in a pan. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 1 minute until aromatic.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until soft and oil starts separating.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, salt, and sugar. Mix well.
Blend the cooked mixture into a smooth puree and return it to the pan.
Add water and simmer the gravy for 5 minutes on low flame.
Add paneer cubes and remaining butter. Cook for 3–4 minutes.
Add fresh cream, garam masala, and crushed kasuri methi. Mix gently and switch off heat.
Serve hot with naan, roti, or jeera rice.

title: Chicken Momos (Street & Restaurant Style)
description: Juicy steamed chicken momos with clear soup, made from scratch with detailed step-by-step instructions

ingredients.name: onion, very finely chopped or grated

steps.instruction: In a bowl, mix maida and salt. Add water gradually and knead into a tight but smooth dough. Cover and rest for 20-30 minutes.

Add minced chicken to a bowl. Add onion, ginger, garlic, spring onion, salt, black pepper, soy sauce, oil, water, vinegar, MSG, and sesame oil. Mix in one direction for 2-3 minutes until sticky and well combined.
Rest the chicken filling for 10 minutes to allow flavors to develop.
Cook 1 teaspoon of filling in a pan to taste-test. Adjust salt or pepper if needed.
Divide rested dough into small balls. Roll each ball into a thin circle (8-9 cm), keeping edges thinner than the center.
Place 1 tablespoon filling in the center of each wrapper. Fold into a half-moon or pleated shape and seal edges firmly.
Grease steamer plate lightly and arrange momos with space between them. Steam on medium heat for 10-12 minutes until wrappers turn glossy and slightly transparent.
Heat a pan with a few drops of oil. Add chopped ginger and garlic on low flame. Add water or stock, salt, and pepper. Boil for 5 minutes.
Add soy sauce and vinegar to the soup. Add steamed momos and simmer gently for 2 minutes only.
Add spring onion greens, switch off heat, and serve momos hot with clear soup and red chilli chutney.

title: Sil-Batta Duck Curry (Slow Cooked, Rice Style)
description: Deep-flavoured Indian duck curry made using traditional sil-batta ground masala, slow cooked for maximum tenderness and best served with rice

ingredients.name: tomato puree or finely chopped tomatoes

steps.instruction: Clean duck meat thoroughly. Rub with turmeric, salt, and vinegar or lemon juice. Set aside for 10 minutes, rinse lightly, and drain.
On a sil-batta, grind black peppercorns, coriander seeds, cumin seeds, fennel seeds, cloves, and cardamom with a little water to a coarse paste.
On the same sil-batta, grind ginger, garlic, and green chillies to a fine paste.
Marinate duck with ground spice paste, ginger-garlic-chilli paste, turmeric, salt, and vinegar. Massage well, cover, and rest for 3–4 hours (minimum 1 hour).
Heat oil in a heavy-bottom pan. Add bay leaves, cinnamon, cardamom, cloves, and star anise. Let them crackle and release aroma.
Add sliced onions and cook on medium-low heat until deep golden brown, stirring frequently to avoid burning.
Add extra ginger-garlic paste (if using) and curry leaves. Sauté until raw smell disappears. Add tomato puree and cook till oil separates.
Add Kashmiri chilli powder, red chilli powder, coriander powder, and garam masala. Cook on low flame for 2 minutes.
Add marinated duck along with all masala. Increase heat and fry for 6–8 minutes until duck releases fat and masala coats evenly.
Add hot water, mix well, cover, and slow cook on low flame for 45–60 minutes, stirring every 10 minutes until duck becomes tender.
Add coconut milk, crushed black pepper, and finishing garam masala. Simmer uncovered for 8–10 minutes until gravy thickens.
Switch off heat and let curry rest for 10 minutes. Garnish with fresh coriander and serve hot with steamed rice.
